G.L. c. 185C, \u00a73.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 185C, §3 and G.L. c. 218, §19, as this matter concerns residential rental property located in Chelsea, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a719.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 185C, §3 and G.L. c. 218, §19, as this matter concerns residential rental property located in Chelsea, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a714.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, §14, a landlord who directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of the leased premises shall be liable to the tenant for actual and consequential damages or, alternatively, for not less than three months’ rent, whichever is greater.

Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.raw_text: Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.480 and 410.750
Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.proposition: Defendant’s omission further violates public policy embodied in the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.480 and 410.750, which require landlords to maintain doors and locks in good repair and in a condition safe for tenants.

*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.proposition: Defendant’s conduct violated the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment recognized under Massachusetts law.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that the landlords breached the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law because their conduct in leasing and allowing operation of the noisy lounge, which they had the right and ability to control, resulted in substantial deprivation of the tenants’ quiet enjoyment. The court explicitly rejects the need for subjective intent and focuses on the landlord’s conduct and its natural and probable consequences, affirming judgments for the tenants on that basis.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.relevant_excerpt: "He ruled that the tenants’ implied warranty of quiet enjoyment was violated by late evening and early morning music and disturbances coming from nearby premises which the landlords leased to others for use as a bar or cocktail lounge... There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done... Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable."

*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Defendant’s conduct violated the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment recognized under Massachusetts law.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly analyzes the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law, ties it to G.L. c. 186, § 14, and applies it to the landlord’s conduct in allowing repeated, preventable flooding. The court holds that such conduct constituted an interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment and that Gem was liable under § 14, even though the separate $10,000 damage award for quiet enjoyment was later vacated as duplicative. Thus, the case squarely supports the proposition that the defendant’s conduct violated the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The common law background of § 14 also suggests that malicious intent is not a condition of liability. The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy… Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy… When the Legislature chose the words ‘quiet enjoyment’… it must have intended to incorporate these cases into the statute… [G]em is liable to Solomon under G. L. c. 186, § 14 because it… permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”}

*Brown v. LeClair*, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 97.proposition: Defendant’s omission further violates public policy embodied in the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.480 and 410.750, which require landlords to maintain doors and locks in good repair and in a condition safe for tenants.
*Brown v. LeClair*, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 97.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly ties the landlord’s liability for the assault to a violation of the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code concerning door security. The court affirms the trial judge’s finding that the flimsy, hollow-core front door did not provide adequate security and was in violation of the State Sanitary Code, and it upholds damages on that basis. That directly supports using the Sanitary Code provisions on doors/locks as a public-policy standard requiring landlords to maintain doors in a condition safe for tenants.
*Brown v. LeClair*, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 97.relevant_excerpt: The judge found that the construction of the door to LeClair’s apartment did not provide adequate security and was in violation of the State Sanitary Code. See c. II of the State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Reg. 410.000 et seq. (1980); Regulations of the Attorney General, 940 Code Mass. Regs. § 3.16(3) (1978). There was evidence that the door was of flimsy construction. The question whether the requisite causal connection has been shown is one of fact... We are unable to say that the findings of the judge on this issue were clearly erroneous.

*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.raw_text: *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that a landlord’s failure to correct security or maintenance problems after notice can support a claim under G.L. c. 186, §14.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.support_reasoning: The court squarely holds that a landlord’s omissions after notice—specifically, failing to take available measures to address dangerous criminal activity—can constitute a breach of G.L. c. 186, § 14. The opinion reverses summary judgment on the quiet enjoyment claim and explains that if, after tenant complaints, the landlord takes no or inadequate action to remove persons engaged in unlawful activity, that failure may be a “natural and probable consequence” causing serious interference with tenancy, thus supporting liability under § 14. This directly supports using § 14 where a landlord fails to correct security problems after notice.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “We do believe, however, that if the defendant has failed to take any measures, especially those measures which can be undertaken relatively easily, to remove unwelcome persons from the property that it owns and controls, and the presence of those persons seriously interferes with the tenancy, then the defendant may be liable for a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. … If the defendant has taken no action or inadequate action, despite covenanting that the plaintiffs’ right to quiet enjoyment shall not be interfered with, then the plaintiffs will be entitled to judgment… See G. L. c. 186, § 14.”

*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that a landlord’s failure to correct security or maintenance problems after notice can support a claim under G.L. c. 186, §14.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.support_reasoning: The opinion directly reiterates that under G.L. c. 186, §14, a landlord’s negligent failure to repair known defects or correct known problems after notice can violate the covenant of quiet enjoyment. In discussing prior precedents, the Court expressly notes that a landlord’s failure to repair defects of which he has notice has "frequently" been deemed a §14 violation, citing cases involving failure to repair or maintain conditions. Thus, the case supports the proposition that uncorrected security or maintenance problems after notice can support a §14 claim.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.relevant_excerpt: We noted that a landlord’s failure “to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.” See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so).

*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that a landlord’s failure to correct security or maintenance problems after notice can support a claim under G.L. c. 186, §14.
*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion deals with a landlord’s failure to provide heat and holds that such conduct, regardless of financial inability, violates G.L. c. 186, §14 as a breach of quiet enjoyment. It does not discuss security or general maintenance problems, nor does it address the significance of prior notice or a pattern of Massachusetts decisions on such issues. Accordingly, it does not support the broader proposition about security or maintenance defects after notice under §14.
*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season…seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’…and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment… It is not necessary to recovery that the landlord intended to violate the covenant. Rather ‘the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.’ … On the facts found by the judge, the tenant was entitled on the quiet enjoyment claim to (a) a declaration that the landlords had violated G. L. c. 186, § 14… and (c) an assessment of damages and counsel fees under § 14.”

*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that a landlord’s failure to correct security or maintenance problems after notice can support a claim under G.L. c. 186, §14.
*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss G.L. c. 186, §14 at all, nor does it address landlord liability for failing to correct security or maintenance problems after notice. The tenant’s negligence/maintenance counterclaim was expressly not appealed, and the only statutory claims analyzed concern the security deposit statute (G.L. c. 186, §15B), rent control, warranty of habitability, and G.L. c. 93A. Because §14 and the specific issue of failure to correct security or maintenance issues after notice are never reached, this case cannot be cited as authority for the proposition stated.
*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt:
"The tenant has not appealed from the dismissal of her counterclaim which alleged that the premises were negligently maintained.

The violations include the existence of lead paint, cracked windows, missing window screens, stained ceiling, loose bathroom tiles, mice, ants, missing balustrades on the porches, inadequate trash receptables, and inadequate door locks."

*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855 (199.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that a landlord’s failure to correct security or maintenance problems after notice can support a claim under G.L. c. 186, §14.
*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855 (199.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns counterclaims for breach of warranty of habitability, quiet enjoyment, negligence, emotional distress, retaliation, and G.L. c. 93A, but it does not analyze or apply G.L. c. 186, §14 specifically to a landlord’s failure to correct security or maintenance problems after notice. The discussion focuses on habitability, emotional distress, damages calculations, and Chapter 93A, not on the scope or consistent interpretation of §14. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for the claimed proposition about §14 liability for uncorrected security/maintenance issues after notice.
*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855 (199.relevant_excerpt:
After her landlord, the plaintiff Nick Haddad, commenced a summary process action… the defendant, Luz Gonzalez, filed six counterclaims alleging: (1) breach of the implied warranty of habitability; (2) breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment in violation of G.L.c. 186, § 14 (1990 ed.); … After a trial, a judge… found in favor of Gonzalez on all of her counterclaims and awarded her damages under c. 186…

[The opinion contains no substantive analysis of §14’s scope regarding failure to repair security or maintenance problems after notice.]

*Farrah v. Peabody Props., Inc.*, 19 Mas.raw_text: *Farrah v. Peabody Props., Inc.*, 19 Mass. L. Rptr. 32 (Mass. Super. Ct. 2005)
*Farrah v. Peabody Props., Inc.*, 19 Mas.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that a landlord’s failure to correct security or maintenance problems after notice can support a claim under G.L. c. 186, §14.
*Farrah v. Peabody Props., Inc.*, 19 Mas.case_name: Massachusetts Port Authority v. Employers Insurance of Wausau
*Farrah v. Peabody Props., Inc.*, 19 Mas.support_reasoning: The opinion in Farrah v. Peabody Props., Inc. as provided here does not discuss landlord-tenant law, residential security or maintenance conditions, or G.L. c. 186, §14 at all. It focuses on summary judgment standards and Chapter 93A/176D unfair claim settlement practices in an insurance dispute involving MassPort and Wausau. Because the case neither interprets nor applies c. 186, §14, it cannot be authority for the proposition that failure to correct security or maintenance problems after notice can support a claim under that statute.
*Farrah v. Peabody Props., Inc.*, 19 Mas.relevant_excerpt: MassPort alleges that Wausau committed three unfair claim settlement practices prohibited and actionable under c. 93A, 9(1) and c. 176D, 3(9). The alleged unfair practices are (a) “failing to effectuate prompt, fair and equitable settlements of claims in which liability has become reasonable clear”; (b) “refusing to pay claims without conducting a reasonable investigation based upon available information”; and (c) “compelling insureds to institute litigation to recover amounts due under an insurance policy by offering substantially less than the amounts ultimately recovered in actions brought by such insured.”

*Hemingway v. O\u2019Brien*, 363 Mass. 3.proposition: The defendant’s conduct also constitutes negligence per se under the State Sanitary Code, further supporting the inference of substantial interference.
*Hemingway v. O\u2019Brien*, 363 Mass. 3.case_name: Board of Appeals of Hanover v. Housing Appeals Comm.
*Hemingway v. O\u2019Brien*, 363 Mass. 3.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns zoning, comprehensive permits, and the Housing Appeals Committee under G.L. c. 40B; it does not involve private tort claims, negligence doctrine, or the State Sanitary Code. Nowhere does the court discuss negligence per se or treat any sanitary code violation as establishing civil liability or ‘substantial interference.’ Accordingly, this case cannot be cited as authority for the proposition that the defendant’s conduct constitutes negligence per se under the State Sanitary Code.
*Hemingway v. O\u2019Brien*, 363 Mass. 3.relevant_excerpt: The legislative history of c. 774 begins with a 1967 Senate Order, No. 933, which directed the Legislative Research Council (Council) to “undertake a study and investigation relative to the feasibility and implications of restricting the zoning power to cities and county governments with particular emphasis on the possibility that the smaller communities are utilizing the zoning power in an unjust manner with respect to minority groups.” ... Therefore, we hold that c. 774 confers on boards of appeals and the Housing Appeals Committee the power to override local “requirements and regulations,” including zoning ordinances or by-laws, which are not “consistent with local needs.”
